bestBHT.bht: The signs described here are unique to Luke and emphasize the impending destruction of Jerusalem and the final coming of Christ. They evoke distress, perplexity, and anguish, bringing to mind the roaring of the sea with its unsteady motion and billows. These signs indicate extraordinary storms and tempests that cause great uneasiness. Prior to the great day, there will be different signs that signify the approaching fulfillment of events.

Henry Alford: The greater part of these signs are peculiar to Luke.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Though the grandeur of this language carries the mind over the head of all periods but that of Christ's second coming...
Nearly every expression will be found used of the Lord's coming in terrible national judgments...
It seems undeniable that its immediate reference was to the destruction of Jerusalem, though its ultimate reference beyond doubt is to Christ's final coming.
Marvin Vincent: Distress [συνοχη] . Only here and 2 Corinthians 2:4. Kindred with sunecomenh, taken (ch. 4 38), on which see note. The original idea of the word is being held in a tight grasp.

With perplexity, the sea and the waves roaring. The A. V. follows the reading hjcoushv, the participle, roaring. The proper reading is hjcouv, the noun, the roaring. Render perplexity for the roaring of the sea, etc.
Waves [σαλου] . Only here in New Testament. The radical notion of the word is unsteady motion, especially the rolling swell of the sea. Rev., better, billows.
Archibald T. Robertson: Distress (συνοχη). From συνεχω. In the N.T. only here and 2 Corinthians 2:4. Anguish.
In perplexity (εν απορια). State of one who is απορος, who has lost his way (α privative and πορος). Here only in the N.T. though an old and common word.
For the roaring of the sea (ηχους θαλασσης). Our word echo (Latin echo) is this word ηχος, a reverberating sound. Sense of rumour in Luke 4:37.
John Gill: They shall fall from heaven, as in Matthew 24:29 and so the Ethiopic version reads here: all which, as it may be understood in a literal sense, so it may likewise in figurative and mystical one.

By the 'sun' they understand the kingdom of the house of David; by 'the light', the law; by 'the moon', the sanhedrim; and by the stars, the Rabbins; and the same seem to be designed by the stars here.

the sea and the waves roaring; which design some unusual and extraordinary storms and tempests, and inundations in the sea of Galilee, or Tiberias, which would be so very terrible, as to cause great uneasiness, distress, and perplexity.
John Wesley: And there shall be — Before the great day, which was typified by the destruction of Jerusalem: signs - Different from those mentioned Luke 21:11, etc. Matthew 24:29; Mark 13:24.

bhtAttempts.bht: The signs described in this verse are unique to Luke and carry a language that surpasses any period except for the second coming of Christ. While these signs primarily refer to the destruction of Jerusalem, they ultimately point to Christ's final coming. The distress and perplexity mentioned here convey the idea of being held in a tight grasp and losing one's way. The roaring of the sea signifies billows and the unsteady motion of the waves. These signs signify unusual and extraordinary storms, tempests, and inundations that would cause great distress and perplexity. Before the great day, there will be signs different from those mentioned earlier.

The signs described in this passage, unique to Luke, point to both the destruction of Jerusalem and the final coming of Christ. They evoke a sense of distress, perplexity, and anguish, as well as the roaring of the sea with its unsteady motion and billows. These signs represent unusual storms, tempests, and inundations that cause great uneasiness. Prior to the great day, there will be different signs that indicate the approaching fulfillment of events.

These signs indicate extraordinary storms and tempests that cause great uneasiness. Prior to the great day, there will be different signs that signify the approaching fulfillment of events.

The signs described in this verse, which are distinct to Luke, refer to both the destruction of Jerusalem and the final coming of Christ. They evoke distress, perplexity, and anguish, akin to being tightly grasped and losing one's way. The roaring of the sea signifies billows and the unsteady motion of the waves. These signs point to extraordinary storms and tempests, causing great distress and perplexity. Before the great day arrives, there will be different signs, signaling the approaching fulfillment of events.

The signs described here, unique to Luke, pertain to the destruction of Jerusalem and the final coming of Christ. They convey distress, perplexity, and the billowing roar of the sea. These signs signify extraordinary storms and tempests that cause great unease. Prior to the great day, there will be different signs, indicating the imminent fulfillment of events.
